child: said I could go out.
dad: No, I didn’t!

man: needs an ambulance.

option: Strangers <item>are not liked</item> in my village.

question.answer: They don’t like strangers in my village.

question.text: <item>I woman</item> know things <item>you man</item> will never understand.

<item>Us women</item> understand these things better than <item>you men</item>.

feedback.desc:
173.10
Though D is possible, it is very informal and considered wrong in formal usage.

question.text: <item>He</item> who hesitates is sometimes lost.

feedback.desc:
This structure is very formal and unusual in modern English.
174.9

exercise.rubric: Is this use of its right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: I’ve had my breakfast and the dog’s had its.

exercise.rubric: All of these sentences are wrong. Why?

question.input_text:
One speaks English in this shop.
One is knocking at the door.
In the 16th century one believed in witches.

exercise.answer: One is only used for generalisations that could include the speaker/hearer.

exercise.rubric: This sentence is also wrong. Why?

question.input_text: <item>One</item> speaks a strange dialect where I come from.

exercise.answer: One is used to generalise about the behaviour of individuals; it doesn’t refer to the collective behaviour of whole groups.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: She often talks to <item>herself</item> when she’s alone.
She always takes her dog with <item>herself</item> when she goes out.

exercise.rubric: Is the use of yourself (instead of you) in these sentences necessary (N), optional (O) or wrong (W)?

question.text: It shouldn’t be difficult for a clever person like <item>yourself</item>.
I have something here that will be very interesting for <item>yourself</item>.
Why don’t you give <item>yourself</item> a break from what you’re doing?

exercise.rubric: Are the reflexive pronouns in these sentences necessary (N), optional (O) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Hurry <item>yourself</item>!
I don’t always shave <item>myself</item> as soon as I get up.
She’s old enough to dress <item>herself</item> now.
His book’s selling <item>itself</item> well.
I feel <item>myself</item> very depressed these days.
The door slowly opened <item>itself</item>.
Concentrate <item>yourself</item>!
Which is more normal: A or B?
option: They each listened carefully to what <item>the other</item> said.
They listened carefully to what <item>each other</item> said.
question.answer: They each listened carefully to what the other said.

feedback.desc:
179.2
B is possible in very informal speech.
